stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spear-Phishing Email Using "Fwd: Syria attack video moves UN to tears" Theme Containing Malicious Attachment
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: On April 19, 2015, US-CERT was notified by a trusted third party of a spear-phishing campaign using "Fwd: Syria attack video moves UN to tears" themed email containing a malicious attachment.

marking:Marking_Structure.simpleMarking:Statement: This Indicator Bulletin is provided "as is" for informational purposes only. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) does not provide any warranties of any kind regarding any information contained within. The DHS does not endorse any commercial product or service, referenced in this bulletin or otherwise. This document is marked TLP: AMBER. Recipients may only share TLP: AMBER information with members of their own organization, and only as widely as necessary to act on that information. For more information on the Traffic Light Protocol, see http://www.us-cert.gov/tlp.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
----- BEGIN EMAIL BODY -----
---------- Forwarded message ---------- From: hewitt hasnain<hasnain.hewitt@gmail.com> Date:2015-04-17 17:30 GMT+08:00 Subject: Syria attack video moves UN to tears To: Mitchell Helen <helen.mitchell.dfat@gmail.com>
A video showing desperate attempts by doctors to save three children after an apparent chlorine gas attack in Syria moves UN Security Council members to tears.
----- END EMAIL BODY -----

EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:Subject: Fwd: Syria attack video moves UN to tears

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description: When run in Microsoft Word 2007 the document takes advantage of vulnerability CVE-2012-0158 to drop two benign word documents, both named "Chlorine Video.doc" (located in different directories) and a malicious executable named "word.exe". It then executes "word.exe" and the "Chlorine Video.doc" file located in C:\Documents and Settings\User\Local Settings\Temp.
This is a benign MS Word document.
This is a benign MS Word document.

The implant displays the icon of a Microsoft Word Document. It runs the following command: C:\WINDOWS\system32\cmd.exe /c reg add hkcu\software\microsoft\windows\currentversion\run /v hotkey /t reg_sz /d ""C:\DOCUME~1\ADMINI~1\LOCALS~1\Temp\update.exe -st"" /f & move ""C:\DOCUME~1\ADMINI~1\LOCALS~1\Temp\word.exe"" ""C:\DOCUME~1\ADMINI~1\LOCALS~1\Temp\update.exe"". The command adds persistence by installing a registry key and also moves "%temp%\word.exe" to "%temp%\update.exe".
The implant will execute on next login/reboot and makes a DNS query for: "apple.dnsrd.com". A connection is attempted to port 443. If successful, an HTTP GET request is sent.
